data.title: Cursor placement when code is folded
data.body:
Hi!

If you click in the first line of a folded code, the cursor is placed at the start of the line, if you type that line is moved.
The cursor should be placed at the end of the line and if you type, the line shouldn't be moved.

data.title: Disabling a package doesn't completely disable it
data.body:
It appears that, even if a package is disabled, other packages can still reach into it and use it.  For example, if I disable vim-mode, vim-surround can still require vim-mode's files and bring its functionality into the editor.  This can lead to some pretty profound surprises.  ("but wait...  I _disabled_ vim-mode!")

I would expect that, if a package is disabled, then it's completely unavailable.

From https://github.com/gepoch/vim-surround/issues/21#issuecomment-118548512

data.title: Open file from command line with line-column didn't work in Windows
data.body:
Opening file from command line with line-column didn't work in Windows (particularly on Windows 8.1 and Atom 1.0.0).

Both

```
> atom.cmd article.tex:22:10
```

and

```
> atom.cmd "article.tex:22:10"
```

Didn't work as expected, it open the file `article.tex:22:10` and not the `article.tex` on line 22 and column 10.

data.title: Unsaved changes lost if permission denied when saving on exit
data.body:
If I open a file that I do not have permission to save and try to save it I get a popup telling me I lack permissions, e.g. `Unable to save file: permission denied '/etc/hosts'`. This seems reasonable (although I wish it would ask me for my sudo password instead).
However, if I modify it and then close it, Atom will ask me if I want to save it, and when I click "yes", it closes the file and gives me that same popup that it failed to save. This means my work is lost. I don't think I have used an editor before that doesn't keep the file open if it fails to save and I believe this should be considered a bug, right?

I am on Chakra linux running 1.0.0 via http://chakraos.org/ccr/packages.php?ID=7252

data.title: Click and drag to highlight characters on Linux
data.body: On linux, clicking and dragging doesn't highlight any characters. Double clicking a word highlights a word and a triple click highlights the line. Should you be able to click and drag to highlight character by character or not?

data.title: Serious energy consumption problem when animating.
data.body: Atom version: 1.0.0 OS: OS X 10.10.3 I found an energy consumption problem when I install or upgrade packages. Atom shows animation when I click the Install or Update buttom, and it will cause a high CPU consumption: The impact on energy consumption has risen to 234.6 in total.Under normal circumstances, it won't be so dramatic. Have any idea about these issue or how can I find the solution to this problem?

data.title: Cache in wrong directory in Linux(?)
data.body:
Atom seems to store its cache under ~/.config/Atom/Cache
I think that might not be the "best" or correct place. I think caches should be placed under ~/.cache/Atom

data.title: Something is putting garbage in my package.json folder.
data.body:
Something is frequently putting garbage json in my `package.json` file.  This mess makes editing `package.json` harder and causes me work to delete it.

In general package.json is _my_ configuration file and something messing with my file really bothers me.  And storing data in an `ini` type file violates many principles including separation of concerns.

I'm posting this issue here because I have a vague memory of discussion here about putting something in `package.json`.

data.title: Different title for file dialogs and folder dialogs.
data.body:
Fixes #6796
If the dialog opens a file its title is changed to "Open File", and if it opens a directory its title is changed to "Open Folder".

data.title: WIP: Use default cursor instead of pointer
data.body:
Refs https://github.com/atom/settings-view/issues/531

This implements something @simurai and I have been throwing around for awhile now – it removes all Atom core usage of `cursor: pointer` in favor of `cursor: default`. As @jerone put it in https://github.com/atom/settings-view/issues/531:

> Showing the cursor as a "hand" when hovering over things in the UI is a very "web" oriented convention.

This will go a long way, I think, toward making Atom feel less like a """website""" running in a semi-headless Chrome, and far more like a native app with a custom UI. :smile: 

_Note: This won't affect the styling of any components that explicitly declare another `cursor` type._

> But how will I know I can click on a thing? How will I know if a thing can be interacted with?

Here's how various OSes and desktop shells handle this:
- **OS X**: Occasionally a hover state, often a thing that looks like a button, but usually no way of knowing other than by clicking on it.
- **Windows**: Hover states.
- **GNOME 3**: Hover states.
- **Ubuntu Unity**: Hover states.

I think the safest bet here is to give actionable elements appropriate hover states as a replacement for `cursor: pointer`.

Although this is quite a sweeping change, it doesn't _entirely_ do away with `cursor: pointer` – the pointer should still be used when an element actually is an external link (whether it's an `a` element or not). Ideally this will be combined with https://github.com/atom/status-bar/issues/89 eventually.

TODO:
- [x] What do we do about actionable text? Right now it'll have a standard link-like underline hover state, but without `cursor: pointer`.
- [x] ~~We could be more extreme and add an `!important` flag to really discourage use of `cursor: pointer` – thoughts?~~
- [ ] Ensure that no other Bootstrap classes need overrides
- [ ] Add `.link-external` class example to styleguide
- [ ] Add `.link-internal` class example to styleguide
- [ ] Add `.text-selectable` class example to styleguide
- [x] Remove all remaining uses of `cursor: pointer` from settings-view (https://github.com/atom/settings-view/pull/575)
- [ ] Ensure that all actionable status bar tiles have hover states
  - [ ] Update status bar tile hover states to look less like links (background highlight maybe?)
- [ ] Communicate this change well so package authors can adapt if need be
  - [ ] Also encourage package authors to use `cursor: default` + hover state for actionable elements in their packages over `cursor: pointer`

/cc @atom/feedback

data.title: Bundled Node/IO.js inconsistencies on Windows 8.1 and 10
data.body:
I'm trying access registry values in Windows that differ in location with each versions of Windows.
Example: https://github.com/Cirex/atom-metro-ui/commit/cfc0ec218a807c7d1e820862940b9c03c121535e

The preferred way to detect the current operating system version seems to be the use of `os.release`, but it's return value differs greatly when used from inside of Atom/Electron.

Locally installed IO.js:

```
> process.version
'v1.5.1'
> os.release()
'6.3.9600'
```

The same command run from the Atom developer console:

```
> process.version
'v1.5.1'
> os.release()
'6.2.9200'
```

My Windows release (8.1) as reported by running `ver` and `winver`:

```
Microsoft Windows [Version 6.3.9600]
```

This bug seems to be related to the embedded manifest file `node.exe.extra.manifest` in Node, and `os.release` use of `GetVersionEx` on Windows.

Can this please be fixed or do I need to use another way of determining the current version of Windows?

data.title: Panes: redundancy in 'close other pane-items/tabs'
data.body:
There have been requests for an Emacs-like behavior of `ctrl-x 1` that would close inactive panes and the closest approach is the 'close other items', but it only closes inactive items within the active pane. To that end the tabs module provides a 'close other tabs' function that does exactly the same thing.

The pane function: 'close other items' could either be omitted or replaced with a 'close other panes' function which would make Emacs users happy.

Multiple items within a pane does not seem to have a purpose without some implementation of tabs. In that case, in my opinion, it should be up to the tabs implementation to provide the 'close other items' feature.

data.title: Allow separate config for dev mode
data.body:
As I was working on https://github.com/atom/atom-dark-ui/pull/48, I realized that it would be really helpful to have a window with Atom Dark UI _and_ a window with One Dark UI up at the same time, to be able to compare differences in styling between the two. 

Currently that's not possible, because dev mode windows necessarily share the same config with regular Atom windows, so changing the theme in one window will always change the theme in all windows.

It would be awesome if you could scope config to dev mode, so you can tailor Atom as needed for your development windows.

data.title: status-bar@0.75.1
data.body: This fixes the color for the path tile in the status bar.

data.title: "Updating" status hangs while updating packages
data.body:
During package updates the "Updating" status of many (not all) packages doesn't seem to change to "Updated" even after the updates have been successfully installed. I can see the updates were successfully installed by clicking "Check for Updates" again after which the "Updating" message disappears and I get the message "All of your installed packages are up to date!".

The issue only appeared after the 1.0.0 release and mostly with some of the larger packages. I realise that larger packages take longer to install but I've tested by waiting more than 10 min and then checking for updates again.

This is not a major issue – in the past I usually waited for conformation that all packages were installed before I continued working where now I have to allow enough time to ensure the process has successfully run.

System specs:
MacBook Pro 17" 2011
Mac OS X Yosemite (10.10.4)
Atom Version 1.0.0

Thx!
(PS. I've tried pretty much all available editors and Atom is by far the best.)

data.title: xml grammar follow brackets in comment
data.body:
Hi All

I'm new to Atom (long time gedit user, but I think this is my new editor :) ).

I think there's a bug in the grammar for xml, when at closing bracket is seen in a comment the grammar colouring follows that?

``` XML
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8' ?>

<!DOCTYPE root [
  <!ENTITY Temp_0 '127.0' >        <!-- Target temperature -->
  <!ENTITY Temp_400 '107.55' >  <!-- [degree C]-->
  <!ENTITY Temp_600 '107.6'>    <!-- [degree C] -->
]>
```

hehe the same happens here when using the colouring possibility :) Why this issue? Gedit highlight fine passing the comment parts...
